page.title: 03ACIDIFICATION OF THE RIVERS
page.content: In this section of the Wye the quality of the trout fishing has declined over the last two decades and the numbers of grayling and chub have increased. This might be due in part to the acidification of the rivers in recent times. The acidity of the nearby River Irfon has changed from pH7 (near neutral) in 1963 to about pH4.7 (near the acidity of vinegar) today. The problems of acidity are not as bad where there is lime in the water to neutralise it. Crayfish require lime for their shells, so are indicators of lime, (calcium), in the water. Crayfish are not found in any streams further upstream on the Wye than the Dulas at Cwmbach. In many parts of Britain "crayfish plague" a fungal disease has killed the Briish crayfish but not in this area yet, fortunately.
